Hello, this is 6Mint English from BBC Learning English. I'm Rob.
And I'm Sam and I'm having a boiled egg for lunch today.
I'll just sprinkle some salt on top there.
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, you’ve spilled some salt on the floor, Sam!
speaker: Rob

text: Quick, throw some over your left shoulder.
Throw salt over my shoulder. What are you talking about, Rob?
It’s bad luck to spill salt!
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, dear. It looks like Rob believes in superstitions.
Old beliefs which are based on magic and mystery rather than science.
Many superstitions are connected to food, as we'll discover in this programme.
Right - like throwing salt over your shoulder to stop bad luck
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, come on, Rob. You don't really believe that, do you?
Well, lots of people do believe food superstitions,
speaker: Rob

text: including otherwise rational, scientific people.
For example, have you ever blown out the candles on a birthday cake made a wish
or thrown rice over the bride and groom at a wedding?
Yes, to both of those. Maybe I'm more superstitious than I thought.
Well, before we find out, it’s time for a quiz question
speaker: Rob

text: about another famous food festival, Halloween.
Ah, that's when people carve scary faces into pumpkins to frighten away evil spirits.
Yes, right. The tradition of carving pumpkins, or jack-a-lantons, as they're called in the United
States, started out as a Celtic festival in Ireland.
speaker: Rob

text: But it was the Americans who started using pumpkins.
So what vegetable did the Irish originally use to scare away ghosts?
Was it a turnips, beabotatos or sea squash?
I'll say B, potatoes.
speaker: Rob

text: Okay, Sam, we'll find out the right answer later on.
What's for sure is that cultures from around the world have been connecting food and magic
speaker: Rob

text: for thousands of years, and over time it's created some strange beliefs.
Here's food historian Tasha Marx describing one unusual superstition to BBC World Service programme
The Food Chain.
speaker: Rob

text: When you have superstitions and they sort of mix with science and health and medicine
speaker: superstitions wards offward offevil eye’blanket term

text: and one of the examples of that would be something like garlic, which we all know garlic
words off vampires, but it's also been thought to ward off the evil eye.
And if you've come across the term the evil eye, it's a sort of blanket term that sort of applies to any bad luck.
Tasha says that garlic is believed to ward off vampires, meaning to repel or stop someone from
harming you.
According to this superstition, garlic also keeps away the evil eye, bad luck or magical spells
speaker: evil eye

text: with the power to cause bad things to happen.
Tasha describes the evil eye as a blanket term for any bad luck.
Just as a real blanket covers the different parts of your body,
a blanket term is a phrase that's used to describe many examples of related things.
But food superstitions aren't only about bad luck, they also give our lives meaning.
Johnty Radhagopalan owns a tourist agency in Hyderabad, India, where she introduces visitors
to some of the city's food traditions.
Here she's talking with BBC World Services The Food Chain about a tradition
connected with the Hindu New Year.
Can you spot the different tastes she mentions?
Some of the traditions give you a little bit of a lesson,
speaker: lessonchutney

text: like on every New Year and not the first January, not the Gregorian calendar New Year,
but the Hindu calendar New Year.
We would always be given a, it's a kind of a chutney which is made of all the five days.
So you have sour, you have sweet, you have something bitter in it and your mom would always give it
using that. This is what the rest of the year is going to be. You'll have happiness, you'll have
challenges, you'll have a little sadness, you'll have bitterness in your life, which I think is a very
nice tradition, it prepares you for everything in life.
At Hindu New Year, mothers give their children a special chutney, a mixture of fruit,
spices, sugar and vinegar. Did you spot the chutney's flavours, Sam?
There was sour, sweet and bitter.
speaker: Sam

text: Mothers tell their children that the coming year, like the chutney, will have its own flavours
both good and bad. That's why Johnty says that traditions can teach you a lesson.
They show you what you should or shouldn't do in the future as a result of experience.
speaker: teach (you) a lesson

text: What a lovely way to end our look at food superstitions.
Yes, maybe we should make chutney at Halloween instead of carving pumpkins or whatever vegetable
speaker: Sam

text: Irish originally used. Yes, in my quiz question, I asked you what vegetable was originally used
instead of pumpkins to scare away ghosts. I guessed it was bee potatoes.
Which was the wrong answer. In fact, turnips were originally used, so maybe Irish ghosts are
speaker: Sam

text: smaller than American ones. Okay, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned about superstitions.
Old beliefs which are connected with magic.
speaker: superstitions

text: Garlic is supposed to ward off or keep away dangers like the evil eye, bad luck or harmful magic.
The evil eye is an example of a blanket term. A phrase used to describe many examples of related
speaker: blanket term

text: things. One Indian superstition involves chutney, a food mixing many flavours.
These traditions can teach you a lesson - show you how to act in the future based on your past experience
speaker: teach you a lesson -
